page.title: Questions - Main Clause Content Questions
page.introduction: Depending on the basic word order of your language, questions may be formed with or without fronting an interrogative phrase. Head-final languages (SOV, OVS, and OSV) usually do not have movement of an interrogative phrase in content questions, while head-initial languages (SVO, VOS, and VSO) usually require fronting of an interrogative phrase.

EnglishExample.exItem: Some examples of English main clause content questions are:
Who might have hit the ball?

form.prompt: Key similar examples from your language here:

radioGroup.prompt: For content questions in your language, is an interrogative phrase required to be fronted?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, like English
No, it simply remains in place

radioGroup.prompt: In main clause content questions, are there one or more special question marker particles or complementizers that may occur?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, and it is the same as the Yes/No question marker for main clauses (or both main and embedded clauses)
Yes, but it is different than the Yes/No question marker
No, it is a clitic which attaches to another word
Yes

radioGroup.prompt: Do any of these question markers occur before a fronted interrogative phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, all the question markers occur after any fronted interrogative phrase
Yes, all do

radioGroup.prompt: Can an Aux also be fronted after the interrogative phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No
Yes, some may but others may not

radioGroup.prompt: Now considering only the (normal) question markers which occur after any fronted interrogative phrase, d Do the question markers occur in the same position(s) in main clause content questions as in main clause Yes/No questions?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No, the positions are different or there are no Yes/No question markers in main clauses

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the question marker occur with respect to the rest of the question (other than a fronted interrogative phrase)?
radioGroup.radio: Before
After
Either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the question markers appear on either side of the question?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Can the question markers appear on both sides in the question?
radioGroup.radio: No, only on one side or the other
Yes, and they must appear on both sides
Yes, they may appear on both sides, but only the one in initial position is required

radioGroup.prompt: May a different question marker also occur only in final position?
radioGroup.radio: No
Yes
Yes, they may appear on both sides, but only the one in final position is required

radioGroup.prompt: May a different question marker also occur only in initial position?
radioGroup.radio: No
Yes

radioGroup.prompt: Is a question marker required in every content question?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No, some content questions do not use/need the question marker
No, but an auxiliary is fronted, like in English

radioGroup.prompt: Is an auxiliary required to be fronted in every content question?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No, some content questions do not require a fronted auxiliary, such as content questions which question the subject in English
No, there is no marker or auxiliary fronting in main clause content questions, just fronting of an interrogative phrase and/or a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking

form.instruction: You need to write a CC table pre-pass to separate it so that it stands alone and also make a root entry for this clitic in your lexicon. Give the entry the category C, or add the feature C to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. Also add the feature wh in either case. Mark the Yes/No question markers with the feature -wh. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, no additional feature is needed.

In the lexicon, if this word does not already have the category C, add the feature C to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. Also add the feature wh in either case. Mark the Yes/No question markers with the feature -wh. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, no additional feature is needed.
In the lexicon, mark each of the question markers which may occur before a fronted interrogative phrase with the feature CP-specifier-initial.
In the lexicon, mark those which may occur before a fronted interrogative phrase with the feature CP-specifier-initial. The others will default to - for that feature.

In the lexicon, mark those markers which can only occur initially with the feature CP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature CP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.
